Table 1. Performance improvements of
our AFedPG over other policy gradient methods. We compare the complexity for global convergence in each agent.

Global Time - 𝒪​(tmaxN​ϵ−2.5)𝒪subscript𝑡𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2.5\mathcal{O}(\frac{t_{\max}}{N}{\epsilon}^{-2.5}) 𝒪​(t¯​ϵ−2.5)𝒪¯𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ2.5\mathcal{O}(\bar{t}{\epsilon}^{-2.5})
references: We answer this question in the affirmative by proposing AFedPG, an algorithm that asynchronously updates the global policy using policy gradients from federated agents. The key components of the proposed AFedPG include a delay-adaptive lookahead technique, which addresses the inconsistent arrival times of updates during the training process. The improvement of AFedPG over other approaches is summarized in Table 1. Here, the global time is measured by the number of global updates ×\times time complexity in each iteration. In terms of sample complexity, the federated learning technique brings a linear speedup with respect to the number of agents N𝑁N. As for the global time, AFedPG improves from 𝒪​(tmaxN​ϵ−2.5)𝒪subscript𝑡𝑁superscriptitalic-ϵ2.5\mathcal{O}(\frac{t_{\max}}{N}{\epsilon}^{-2.5}) to 𝒪​(t¯​ϵ−2.5)𝒪¯𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ2.5\mathcal{O}(\bar{t}{\epsilon}^{-2.5}), where t¯≔1/∑i=1N1ti≔¯𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁1subscript𝑡𝑖\bar{t}\coloneqq 1/\sum_{i=1}^{N}\frac{1}{t_{i}} is a harmonic average and always smaller than tmax/Nsubscript𝑡𝑁t_{\max}/N, and tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} denotes the time complexity in each iteration at agent i𝑖i.

Linear speedup in sample complexity: As shown in Table 1, our federated method improves the sample complexity in each agent from 𝒪​(ϵ−2.5)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ2.5\mathcal{O}({\epsilon}^{-2.5}) (single agent PG) to 𝒪​(ϵ−2.5N)𝒪superscriptitalic-ϵ2.5𝑁\mathcal{O}(\frac{{\epsilon}^{-2.5}}{N}), where N𝑁N is the number of federated agents. This represents the linear speedup with respect to the number of agents N𝑁N.

Speedup of sample complexity: First, to verify the improvement of sample complexity in the first row of Table 1, we evaluate the speedup effects of the number of federated agents N𝑁N. In Figure 4, with different numbers of agents, we test the convergence performances of AFedPG (N=2,4,8𝑁248N=2,4,8) and the single agent PG (N=1𝑁1N=1). The x-axis is the number of samples collected by each agent on average, and the y-axis is the reward. In all three MuJoCo tasks, AFedPG beats the single-agent PG: AFedPG converges faster, has lower variances, and achieves higher final rewards when more agents are involved in collecting trajectories and estimating policy gradients. These results confirm the advantage of AFedPG in terms of sample complexity.

Improvement of global time complexity:
Second, to verify the improvement of global time complexity in the second row of Table 1, we compared the time consumption in the asynchronous and synchronous settings. In Figure 5, we set N=4,8𝑁48N=4,~{}8 and fix the number of samples collected by all agents. Here, tmaxsubscript𝑡t_{\max} is about 444 times more than tminsubscript𝑡t_{\min}. The numbers of total samples (trajectories) are 8×1038superscript1038\times 10^{3}, 16×10316superscript10316\times 10^{3}, and 8×1048superscript1048\times 10^{4} for the Swimmer-v4 task, Hopper-v4 task, and Humanoid-v4 task individually when N=8𝑁8N=8. When N=4𝑁4N=4, the numbers are halved. In all three environments, AFedPG has much lower time consumption compared to the synchronous FedPG, confirming the enhancement in terms of time complexity.

references: Environment: To validate the effectiveness of our approach via experiments, we consider three popular MuJoCo environments (Swimmer-v4, Hopper-v4, and Humanoid-v4) (Todorov et al., 2012) with the MIT License. Both the state and action spaces are continuous. Environmental details are described in Table 2 and the MuJoCo tasks are visualized in Figure 3.

references: Implementation: Policies are parameterized by fully connected multi-layer perceptions (MLPs) with settings listed in Table 3. We follow the practical settings in stable-baselines3 (Raffin et al., 2021) to update models with generalized advantage estimation (GAE) (0.950.950.95) (Schulman et al., 2018) in our implementation. We use PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019) to implement deep neural networks (DNNs). All tasks are trained on NVIDIA A100 GPUs with 404040 GB of memory.
